awd_titl_txt: Bidirectional Transport of Lysosome Related Organelles during Synapse Maintenance and Plasticity
awd_abstract_narration:
The human brain is extraordinarily complex consisting of about 86 billion neurons and about the same number of non-neuronal cells.  The neurons communicate with each other through specialized junctions known as synapses. The non-neuronal cells influence these communications. Importantly communications between these cells mediate various brain functions including sensory perception, memory storage, and intelligence. Furthermore, there is also communication within neurons. Inside neurons, long tracks are traveling from one end of the neuron to the other end. Microscopic structures move along these tracks for mediating communication within neurons. Decades of research have established the significance of brain cell communications. However, it is not well understood precisely how these cells influence each other’s communications for brain functions. In this study, the investigative team assesses how the formation of connections between two neurons modifies each other for mediating neuronal communications. To study this complex problem, the team studies neurons of a sea slug that has a much simpler nervous system. Neurons of sea slug are about 10-100 times larger than human neurons. Specifically, using the neurons of sea slug, the team in this project studies communication within neurons and between neurons by imaging the movement of microscopic structures in neurons and its relation to neuronal communication during memory formation. The project also offers high school and undergraduate students to participate in research using cutting-edge techniques, and includes lessons on how the brain is wired for middle school students in Florida.

The complexity of neuronal architecture such as the extensive dendritic branching and axonal terminals necessitates active bidirectional transport of gene products between the cell body and its terminals for synapse function. Several studies, including our own, have indicated that anterograde transport (i.e., towards terminals) facilitates synapse formation and activity-dependent remodeling of synapses, while retrograde transport (i.e., from terminals) serves as signals to the nucleus resulting in transcriptional changes. However, several aspects of this bi-directional transport, such as the regulation, dynamics, and mechanisms of transport during formation, and maintenance and remodeling of synapses are poorly understood. In this project, exploring the advantages of the identified neurons and synapses of the sea slug Aplysia californica, the investigative team addresses these questions by studying the bidirectional transport of lysosome-related organelles (LROs) in presynaptic sensory neurons of Aplysia gill withdrawal reflex. LROs are membrane-bound acidic organelles transported bidirectionally and are involved in degradative pathways. Specifically, the team studies whether and how bidirectional transport of LROs in presynaptic sensory neurons is regulated during formation and maintenance, and excitatory and inhibitory forms of plasticity at sensory-motor neuron synapses of Aplysia gill withdrawal reflex.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how the brain is wired—and how this wiring is maintained and modified—is one of the most fundamental and unresolved challenges in neuroscience. These questions are also central to developing effective, mechanism-based treatments for neuropsychiatric disorders. Our NSF-funded research project aimed to uncover how synaptic connections in the brain are formed, maintained, and modified—key processes that underlie learning, memory, and behavior. To address this, we took advantage of the unique features of the marine sea slug Aplysia californica. This model organism possesses large, easily identifiable neurons and well-characterized neural circuits that control specific learning behaviors, making it an ideal system for investigating how neuronal communication supports synaptic function and plasticity. Neurons are among the most structurally complex cells in the body, with long projections and extensive branching. These intricate structures rely on the precise delivery of gene products—such as proteins and RNAs—from the cell body to distant synaptic terminals (anterograde), and, importantly, in the retrograde direction from synapse back to the cell body. Prior studies, including our own, have shown that this transport is dynamically regulated during learning and that the molecular machinery responsible for moving these gene products plays a critical role in supporting synaptic stability and adaptability.

Despite this knowledge, little was known about how long-distance transport in both directions is modulated during different stages of synapse development and activity. To fill this gap, we used advanced live-cell imaging tools to record the movement of two key types of organelles—mitochondria and lysosomal vesicles—within Aplysia sensory neurons involved in the gill-withdrawal reflex, a well-studied defensive behavior. By comparing organelle transport under different conditions—such as synapse formation, maintenance, and plasticity—we discovered several novel features of intracellular transport. We found that the movement of these organelles is not uniform, but instead varies depending on the type of organelle, the direction of movement, and the functional state of the synapse. Specifically, mitochondrial and lysosomal vesicle transport followed different patterns. The transport also differed depending on whether organelles were moving from the cell body to the synapse or from the synapse back to the cell body. Additionally, these patterns changed depending on whether the neuron was forming new synapses, maintaining existing ones, or undergoing plastic changes. For instance, we found that the maintenance of sensory-motor neuron synaptic connections required an increase in mitochondrial transport in both directions, while retrograde transport of lysosomal vesicles was selectively reduced. When plasticity was induced—a process accompanied by the formation of new synaptic connections and remodeling of existing ones—there was a specific increase in anterograde mitochondrial transport, along with a selective decrease in retrograde transport of lysosomal vesicles.

These findings reveal previously unknown ways in which neurons regulate the transport of intracellular components to support specific synaptic functions. This work advances our understanding of how neural circuits operate and adapt and may have important implications for understanding the cellular basis of learning, memory, and neuropsychiatric disorders.

Broader Impacts

This project also provided meaningful educational and research opportunities for a diverse group of students. Four high school and six undergraduate students received hands-on training in neurobiology, molecular biology, and protein complex analysis using Aplysia. Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows gained experience with advanced methodologies, including super-resolution microscopy and proteomics techniques. Notably, undergraduate student Sebastian Lozano-Villada co-authored two manuscripts stemming from this work, demonstrating the project's strong emphasis on mentorship and training.

Dissemination

Thanks to generous support from the NSF, this project has led to the publication of two peer-reviewed manuscripts. Three additional manuscripts are currently under review, and another is in preparation. These findings are not only contributing to our scientific understanding of synaptic plasticity but are also helping shape future research directions in neuroscience.
